{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox football biography |name = Cuco Martina |image = Audi- quattro-Cup 05.JPG |image_size = 200 |caption = Martina with Southampton in 2015 |fullname = Rhu-endly Aurelio Jean-Carlo Martina{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/612828 |title=Updated squads for 2017/18 Premier League confirmed |publisher=Premier League |date=2 February 2018 |accessdate=11 February 2018}} |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1989|9|25|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Rotterdam]], Netherlands |height = 1.85 m |position = [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|Right back]] |currentclub = [[Feyenoord]]
(on loan from [[Everton F.C.|Everton]]) |clubnumber = 24 |youthyears1 = |youthclubs1 = [[Feyenoord]] |years1 = 2008–2011 |clubs1 = [[RBC Roosendaal]] |caps1 = 68 |goals1 = 2 |years2 = 2011–2013 |clubs2 = [[RKC Waalwijk]] |caps2 = 43 |goals2 = 1 |years3 = 2013–2014 |clubs3 = [[Jong FC Twente|Jong Twente]] |caps3 = 11 |goals3 = 0 |years4 = 2013–2015 |clubs4 = [[FC Twente|Twente]] |caps4 = 48 |goals4 = 1 |years5 = 2015–2017 |clubs5 = [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] |caps5 = 24 |goals5 = 1 |years6 = 2017– |clubs6 = [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] |caps6 = 21 |goals6 = 0 |years7 = 2018–2019 |clubs7 = → [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] (loan) |caps7 = 17 |goals7 = 0 |years8 = 2019– |clubs8 = → [[Feyenoord]] (loan) |caps8 = 0 |goals8 = 0 |nationalyears1 = 2011– |nationalteam1 = [[Curaçao national football team|Curaçao]] |nationalcaps1 = 38 |nationalgoals1 = 1 |club-update = 18:23, 1 January 2019 (UTC) |ntupdate = 23:03, 10 September 2018 (UTC) }} '''Rhu-endly Aurelio Jean-Carlo''' "'''Cuco'''" '''Martina''' (born 25 September 1989) is a professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays for [[Feyenoord]] on loan from [[Premier League]] club [[Everton F.C.|Everton]]. He plays primarily as a [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|right back]], but can also play as a [[Defender (association football)#Centre-back|centre back]] or [[Midfielder#Defensive midfielder|defensive midfielder]]. A youth player at [[Feyenoord]], he began his senior career with [[RBC Roosendaal]] in the [[Eerste Divisie]], followed by two seasons each at [[Eredivisie]] clubs [[RKC Waalwijk]] and [[FC Twente]]. In 2015, he joined [[Premier League]] club [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]], and two years later [[Everton F.C.|Everton]]. Born and raised in the Netherlands, he represents [[Curaçao national football team|Curaçao]] at international level, for whom he is captain. First capped in 2011, he has won the 2017 Caribbean Cup, and he represented the team at the [[2017 CONCACAF Gold Cup]]. ==Early and personal life== Martina was born in [[Rotterdam]]. He grew up in the south of the city with his mother, brothers and sister.{{cite web |url=http://www.twenteinsite.nl/cuco-martina-heet-eigenlijk-rhu-endly.html|title=Cuco Martina heet eigenlijk Rhu-endly|date=27 March 2014|accessdate=7 July 2015| language=Dutch|publisher=Twente Insite}} Martina did not know his father, and states his elder brother was instead like a father to him. His brother [[Javier Martina|Javier]] is also a footballer.{{cite web|url=https://southamptonfc.com/news/2015-07-07/in-profile-cuco-martina |title=In Profile: Cuco Martina|date=7 July 2015|accessdate=7 March 2017|publisher=Southampton F.C.}} [[Derwin Martina|Derwin]] is not related to him, despite media reports to the contrary.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39198728|title=Derwin Martina: York City release defender after playing one game for reserve team|date=7 March 2017|accessdate=7 March 2017|publisher=BBC Sport}} ==Club career== ===Netherlands=== Martina played youth football with [[Feyenoord]]. He spent his early senior career with [[RBC Roosendaal]] in the [[Eerste Divisie]].{{cite web|url=http://www.vi.nl/spelers/carriere/rhuendly-martina.htm|title=Profile|accessdate=7 July 2015|language=Dutch|publisher=Voetbal International}}{{soccerway|cuco-martina/57652|accessdate=26 June 2017}} In 2011, he joined [[RKC Waalwijk]] of the [[Eredivisie]].{{cite news|last1=Ummels|first1=Jody|title=Overzicht van de Brabantse voetbaltransfers|url=http://www.omroepbrabant.nl/?news/157404722/Overzicht+van+de+Brabantse+voetbaltransfers.aspx|publisher=Omroep Brabant|accessdate=26 August 2017|date=27 June 2011|language=Dutch}} He played 59 official matches in two seasons in [[North Brabant]], scoring to open a 2–0 home win over [[N.E.C. (football club)|N.E.C.]] on 8 December 2012.{{cite news|title=Degelijk RKC Waalwijk verslaat dramatisch NEC: 2–0|url=http://www.omroepbrabant.nl/?news/185050572/Degelijk+RKC+Waalwijk+verslaat+dramatisch+NEC+2-0.aspx|accessdate=26 August 2017|publisher=Omroep Brabant|date=8 December 2012|language=Dutch}} On 30 July 2013, he joined [[FC Twente]] on a three-year deal for an undisclosed fee.{{cite news|title=Cuco Martina naar FC Twente|url=http://www.fctwente.nl/blog/2013/07/cuco-martina-naar-fc-twente/|accessdate=26 August 2017|publisher=FC Twente|date=30 July 2013|language=Dutch}} Martina played 59 games across all competitions for the [[Enschede]] club, scoring once: an added-time equaliser in a 2–2 home draw with Feyenoord on 23 February 2014.{{cite news|title=FEYENOORD PEGGED BACK IN INJURY TIME|url=https://www.feyenoord.com/feyenoord-1/results/fc-twente-feyenoord-netherlands-eredivisie-2013-2014/post-match|accessdate=26 August 2017|publisher=Feyenoord|date=23 February 2014}} ===Southampton=== He signed a two-year contract with English club [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] on 7 July 2015.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/33426049|title=Cuco Martina: Southampton sign FC Twente defender|date=7 July 2015|accessdate=7 July 2015|publisher=BBC Sport}} An unused substitute in the first leg,{{cite news|last1=Williams|first1=Adam|title=Southampton 3–0 Vitesse|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33667103|accessdate=9 August 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=30 July 2015}} Martina made his Southampton debut in their [[UEFA Europa League]] third qualifying round second leg away to [[SBV Vitesse|Vitesse Arnhem]], playing the full 90 minutes of a 2–0 win on 6 August.{{cite news|last1=Jennings|first1=Patrick|title=Vitesse 0–2 Southampton|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33738509|accessdate=9 August 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=6 August 2015}} Three days later, he made his league debut as a half-time substitute for fellow new signing [[Cédric Soares]] in a 2–2 draw against [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]].{{cite news|last1=Davis|first1=Matt|title=Newcastle 2–2 Southampton|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33750572|accessdate=9 August 2015|date=9 August 2015}} Martina became the first-ever Curaçao international to play for [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] and the second to play in the [[Premier League]] after [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]]'s [[Shelton Martis]] in 2009. On 26 December 2015, on his first start, Martina scored his only goal for the Saints, a long-range strike to open a 4–0 win over [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]]. He became the first Curaçaoan to score in the Premier League.{{cite news|title=Martina: An unbelievable feeling|url=http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/news/article/20151226-cuco-martina-post-southampton-arsenal-2869805.aspx|accessdate=27 December 2015|publisher=Southampton F.C.|date=26 December 2015}} He was released by Southampton at the end of the 2016–17 season.{{cite web|title=Saints release four players|url=https://southamptonfc.com/news/2017-05-25/southampton-2017-retained-list-players-released|publisher=Southampton FC|accessdate=26 May 2017|date=25 May 2017}} ===Everton=== On 17 July 2017, following his release from Southampton, Martina joined fellow [[Premier League]] side [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] on a three-year deal, reuniting with his former Saints manager [[Ronald Koeman]].{{cite web |title=Blues Swoop For Martina |url=http://www.evertonfc.com/news/2017/07/17/blues-swoop-for-martina |publisher=Everton Official Site |accessdate=17 July 2017 |date=17 July 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40637068 |title=Cuco Martina: Everton sign out-of-contract Southampton defender |publisher= BBC Sport |date=17 July 2017 |accessdate=20 July 2017 }} Martina made his league debut for Everton on 12 August, when his club beat [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] 1–0 at [[Goodison Park]].{{cite news |title=Everton 1–0 Stoke City|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/40835425 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 August 2017 |accessdate=12 August 2017}} Martina joined Stoke, newly relegated to the [[EFL Championship]], on a loan for the [[2018–19 Stoke City F.C. season|2018–19]] season.{{cite web |title=Cuco Martina: Stoke City sign Everton defender on a season-long loan deal |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45224825 |website=BBC Sport |accessdate=17 August 2018}} He made his debut on 25 August, playing the full 90 minutes in a 2–0 home win over [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]].{{cite news |title=Stoke City 2–0 Hull City |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45229933 |accessdate=17 September 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 August 2018}} Martina's loan with Stoke was cancelled on 31 January 2019,{{cite web |title=Martina returns to Everton |url=https://www.stokecityfc.com/news/martina-returns-to-everton |website=Stoke City |accessdate=31 January 2019}} and he re-joined [[Feyenoord]] on loan for the remainder of the [[2018–19 Feyenoord season|2018–19]] season.{{cite web |title=Martina Makes Feyenoord Loan Switch |url=http://www.evertonfc.com/news/2019/01/31/martina |website=Everton |accessdate=31 January 2019}} ==International career== Martina made his international debut for [[Curaçao national football team|Curaçao]] on 9 August 2011, in their first match since the dissolution of the [[Netherlands Antilles national football team|Netherlands Antilles]]. He played the first half of the 1–0 friendly loss to the [[Dominican Republic national football team|Dominican Republic]] at the [[Estadio Panamericano, San Cristóbal|Estadio Panamericano in San Cristóbal]], before being substituted for [[Kenny Kunst]].{{NFT player|pid=44883|accessdate=7 July 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.rkcwaalwijk.nl/rkc-waalwijk-nieuws/zoet-houdt-weer-de-nul-martina-met-curacao-onderuit/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402130941/http://www.rkcwaalwijk.nl/rkc-waalwijk-nieuws/zoet-houdt-weer-de-nul-martina-met-curacao-onderuit/|title=Zoet houdt weer de nul, Martina met Curaçao onderuit|date=7 September 2011|archivedate=2 April 2012|accessdate=7 July 2015|language=Dutch|publisher=RKC Waalwijk}} He has played in qualifying matches for the 2014 and 2018 World Cups.{{FIFA player|347633}} He served as national team captain.{{cite web|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/who-everton-target-cuco-martina-11793958|title=Who is Everton target Cuco Martina? Everything you need to know|date=24 August 2016|accessdate=15 July 2017|author=Connor O'Neill|publisher=Liverpool Echo}} Martina was part of the Curaçao squad that won the [[2017 Caribbean Cup]] in [[Martinique]], defeating [[Jamaica national football team|Jamaica]] 2–1 in the final.{{cite news|last1=Williams|first1=Sean|title=Boyz edged 1–2 by Curacao in Caribbean Cup final|url=http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/sports/boyz-edged-1-2-by-curacao-in-caribbean-cup-final_103087?profile=1511|accessdate=26 August 2017|date=26 June 2017}} He captained the team at the [[2017 CONCACAF Gold Cup]].{{cite web|title=Curaçao 2 – 0 Jamaica|url=http://www.concacaf.com/category/gold-cup/game-detail/393983|publisher=CONCACAF|accessdate=26 August 2017}} ==Career statistics== ===Club=== {{updated|match played 1 January 2019}}{{soccerway|cuco-martina/57652|accessdate=18 December 2015}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |+ Appearances and goals by club, season Scores and results list Curaçao's goal tally first.}} {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" |- !No.!!Date!!Venue!!Opponent!!Score!!Result!!Competition |- | 1. || 10 September 2018 || [[Ergilio Hato Stadium]], [[Willemstad]], Curaçao || {{fb|GRN}} || align=center|'''2'''–0|| align=center|10–0|| [[2019–20 CONCACAF Nations League qualifying|2019–20 CONCACAF Nations League qualification]] |} ==Honours== '''Southampton''' *[[EFL Cup]] runner-up: [[2017 EFL Cup Final|2016–17]] '''Curaçao''' *[[Caribbean Cup]]: [[2017 Caribbean Cup|2017]] '''Individual''' *[[CONCACAF Awards|CONCACAF Best XI]]: [[2018 CONCACAF Awards|2018]]{{cite web|url=https://www.concacaf.com/en/awards/news/mexico-leads-way-in-concacaf-men-s-best-xi|title=Mexico leads way in Concacaf Men’s Best XI|website=www.concacaf.com|date=15 January 2019|accessdate=16 January 2019}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commonscat}} *{{Soccerbase}} {{Feyenoord squad}} {{Curaçao squad 2017 CONCACAF Gold Cup}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Martina, Cuco}} [[Category:1989 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Footballers from Rotterdam]] [[Category:Dutch footballers]] [[Category:Dutch people of Curaçao descent]] [[Category:Curaçao footballers]] [[Category:Curaçao international footballers]] [[Category:Association football fullbacks]] [[Category:Feyenoord players]] [[Category:RBC Roosendaal players]] [[Category:RKC Waalwijk players]] [[Category:FC Twente players]] [[Category:Southampton F.C. players]] [[Category:Everton F.C. players]] [[Category:Stoke City F.C. players]] [[Category:Dutch expatriate footballers]] [[Category:Dutch expatriate sportspeople in England]] [[Category:Expatriate footballers in England]] [[Category:Eredivisie players]] [[Category:Eerste Divisie players]] [[Category:Premier League players]] [[Category:2014 Caribbean Cup players]] [[Category:2017 CONCACAF Gold Cup players]] [[Category:English Football League players]]
